title: Enrichment and Welfare for Uromastyx
description: Enrichment ideas, behavior checks, and handling tips to keep Uromastyx active, secure, and stress-free.
excerpt: Enrichment ideas, behavior checks, and handling tips to keep Uromastyx active, secure, and stress-free.
author: Habitat Builder Team

content.text: Uromastyx are heat-loving, ground-dwelling lizards that thrive when their enclosure gives them choices: bright basking spots, shaded retreats, and places to dig. The goal is a warm, dry habitat with layered texture and multiple safe hideouts.

items: Build a basking platform with stacked stone or sealed wood to create warm crevices.
Provide at least two hides: one on the cool side and one under a warm shelf.
Add a few stable rocks or cork pieces to encourage short climbs and visual barriers.
Leave open floor space for foraging; Uromastyx are active ground walkers.
Use sand or sandy soil deep enough for shallow digging and burrow shaping.
Expect long basking sessions under very bright light; this is normal and healthy.
Watch for regular movement between hot, warm, and cool zones during the day.
Provide a shaded retreat so the lizard can exit the light without leaving the heat gradient.
Give new arrivals 10-14 days to settle before handling.
Offer greens by hand or tongs to build positive association.
Always scoop from below and support the body; avoid grabbing from above.
Keep sessions short and calm; return the lizard if it shows signs of stress.
Body condition: full tail base and smooth hips without sharp bones.
Appetite: steady interest in greens and occasional seeds.
Skin and eyes: clear, no retained shed around toes or tail tip.
Activity: alert and basking during the day, resting in hides at night.
Droppings: regular, well-formed feces with white urates.

rows: Uromastyx need intense heat to digest and stay active.
They may retreat after reaching ideal body temperature.
Give time, keep handling minimal at first.
Check basking temps and ventilation; seek vet if it persists.
Often indicates temperatures or UVB are too low.
Possible metabolic bone disease; seek vet care immediately.

content.content: Red flags: severe lethargy, sunken eyes, blackened tail tip, or refusal to bask for multiple days. Verify temperatures and UVB immediately and consult an experienced reptile vet.

items: Rotate one or two decor items every 6-8 weeks to add novelty without removing all landmarks.
Change feeding spots occasionally to encourage foraging.
Refresh burrow areas by lightly moistening deeper substrate, keeping the surface dry.
